text: I suppose this is more of a math question, but I have a model that I regressed and I believeI'm at the global minima. I went to calculate the confidence intervals on the parameters and I calculated the Jacobian of it for each parameter at each data point. Part of the calculation is (J^T * J) ^-1 the only issue is that the transposed jacobian * jacobian is singular so it can't be done. Does anyone know of another way to do this?

elements.text: I suppose this is more of a math question, but I have a model that I regressed and I believeI'm at the global minima. I went to calculate the confidence intervals on the parameters and I calculated the Jacobian of it for each parameter at each data point. Part of the calculation is (J^T * J) ^-1 the only issue is that the transposed jacobian * jacobian is singular so it can't be done. Does anyone know of another way to do this?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/i-suppose-this-is-more-of-a-math-question-but-i-have-a-model-that-i-regressed-and|to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!
AFAIK, if you use the Jacobian you are making an assumption that the errors are Normal. You can estimate the errors through bootstrapping or using some MCMC process.

elements.text: AFAIK, if you use the Jacobian you are making an assumption that the errors are Normal. You can estimate the errors through bootstrapping or using some MCMC process.

text: Using the Jacobian per se doesn't assume the errors are Normal, I think doing inference may, but CLT will kick in with large enough N. If the problem is ill conditioned then there are some regularization techniques (though then you would have to use bootstrap probably). Also, QR/SVD, etc may make it more stable. I'm guessing this is nonlinear least squares, so there is theory about Levenberg Marquardt which uses a damping parameter that can act as a regularizer sort of: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenberg%E2%80%93Marquardt_algorithm>

text: <@U01EF0QVAB0> Sorry, that’s what i meant. You can estimate non-normal errors with the Jacobian, but you won’t know that they are not Normal.
